alert.note: Alert for Lavaca (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 25 at 1:18AM CST until January 26 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Houston - Galveston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas... Tres Palacios River near Midfield affecting Matagorda and Wharton Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Navidad River at Sublime affecting Lavaca County. For the Tres Palacios River...including Midfield...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Navidad River...including Sublime...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Navidad River at Sublime. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 32.0 feet, Major lowland flooding continues with the river one quarter mile wide at the Highway 90A bridge threatening livestock from the headwaters to below Speaks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:00 AM CST Thursday the stage was 31.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 20.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:00 AM CST Thursday was 31.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 31.6 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight to 10.0 feet Saturday morning. It will rise to 10.4 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall to 8.2 feet early Monday afternoon. It will then rise again but remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 24.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 31.6 feet on 04/18/2009. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (12 am CST) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Fri Sat Sun Navidad River Sublime 24.0 31.4 Thu 1 am CST 27.3 10.7 10.4 &&
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued later this morning.this evening at 730 PM CST.
